meanings.def: an animal with four legs and a tail, often kept as a pet or trained for work, for example hunting or guarding buildings. There are many types of dog, some of which are wild.
examples: I took the dog for a walk.
I'm just going to walk the dog.
I could hear a dog barking.
Stray dogs roamed the streets at night.
dog walkers/owners
dog food/biscuits
a dog and its puppies
A labrador is a breed of dog.
She often stops to chat to other dog walkers.
Owners who allow their dogs to foul the footpath will be fined.
A dog was gnawing at an old bone.
A dog was sniffing around my heels.
Bad dog! What are you doing there?
He's trained his dog to sit on the back of his bike.
She was bitten by a dog.
Races have been held at this dog track for seventy years.
They moved into a flat and couldn't take their pet dog.
He worked for the police as a dog handler.
This is a working dog, not a pet.
The chihuahua is one of the hardest to train of all dog breeds.
Rex was a champion show dog.
They roam the streets like packs of wild dogs.
The dog barked loudly at the stranger.
The dog bounded up to me and started licking my hand.
When it saw him, the dog began wagging its tail.
The dog chewed up one of my shoes.
The dog was scratching at the door to be let in.
The dog went for him and bit him twice on the leg.
The dog's owner was banned from keeping dogs for five years.
The little dogs were yapping at my ankles.
The stray dogs are wormed and treated with flea powder.
These dogs were bred to hunt small animals.
We didn't want puppies so we had the dog neutered.
The dog was dangerous and had to be destroyed, police have confirmed.
We recently had to put our dog to sleep.

meanings.def: a male dog, fox, wolf or otter
greyhound racing
a thing of low quality; a failure
examples: Her last movie was an absolute dog.

meanings.def: an offensive way of describing a woman who is not considered attractive
used, especially after an adjective, to describe a man who has done something bad
examples: You dirty dog!

meanings.def: to be raining heavily
an event that is planned only in order to impress people so that they will support or buy something
examples: the dog and pony show of his visits to the war zone
a dog and pony show to sell the idea to investors

meanings.def: a situation in business, politics, etc. where there is a lot of competition and people are willing to harm each other in order to succeed
examples: I'm afraid in this line of work it's a case of dog eat dog.
We're operating in a dog-eat-dog world.

meanings.def: a person who stops other people from enjoying something that the person cannot use or does not want themselves
a thing that has been done badly
examples: He's made a real dog's breakfast of these accounts.

meanings.def: an unhappy life, full of problems or unfair treatment
examples: He led his poor partner a dog's life.

meanings.def: everyone has good luck or success at some point in their life
when a person already has a bad reputation, it is difficult to change it because others will continue to blame or suspect them
to get into a very bad state
examples: This firm's gone to the dogs since the new management took over.

meanings.def: alcohol that you drink in order to make you feel better when you have drunk too much alcohol the night before
to be involved in a situation so that you will gain or lose according to the result
examples: I really don't have a dog in this fight, so I can just enjoy the game.
The employees have a dog in the hunt, so their views should be listened to.

meanings.def: to avoid mentioning a subject or something that happened in the past, in order to avoid any problems or arguments
extremely hard
examples: I've been working like a dog recently.

meanings.def: in a very bad or cruel way
examples: They treated him like a dog.

meanings.def: very determined and refusing to give up
examples: When she sensed a good story she was like a dog with a bone.

meanings.def: to have no chance at all
examples: He hasn't a dog's chance of passing the exam.

meanings.def: feeling very sick; vomiting a lot
used to describe a situation in which the most important aspect is being influenced and controlled by somebody/something that is not as important
(you cannot) successfully make people change their ideas, methods of work, etc., when they have had them for a long time
to allow somebody to suffer or be punished in an unfair way, as if they have no value
examples: Her boss collects a big retirement cheque while she is thrown to the dogs.

meanings.def: if somebody can do a task for you, there is no point in doing it yourself

idioms.def: to be raining heavily
an event that is planned only in order to impress people so that they will support or buy something
examples: the dog and pony show of his visits to the war zone
a dog and pony show to sell the idea to investors

idioms.def: a situation in business, politics, etc. where there is a lot of competition and people are willing to harm each other in order to succeed
examples: I'm afraid in this line of work it's a case of dog eat dog.
We're operating in a dog-eat-dog world.

idioms.def: a person who stops other people from enjoying something that the person cannot use or does not want themselves
a thing that has been done badly
examples: He's made a real dog's breakfast of these accounts.

idioms.def: an unhappy life, full of problems or unfair treatment
examples: He led his poor partner a dog's life.

idioms.def: everyone has good luck or success at some point in their life

idioms.idiom: give a dog a bad name
idioms.def: when a person already has a bad reputation, it is difficult to change it because others will continue to blame or suspect them
to get into a very bad state
examples: This firm's gone to the dogs since the new management took over.

idioms.idiom: a/the hair of the dog (that bit you)
idioms.def: alcohol that you drink in order to make you feel better when you have drunk too much alcohol the night before

idioms.idiom: have a dog in the fight
idioms.def: to be involved in a situation so that you will gain or lose according to the result
examples: I really don't have a dog in this fight, so I can just enjoy the game.
The employees have a dog in the hunt, so their views should be listened to.

idioms.def: to avoid mentioning a subject or something that happened in the past, in order to avoid any problems or arguments
extremely hard
examples: I've been working like a dog recently.
They treated him like a dog.

idioms.idiom: like a dog with a bone
idioms.def: very determined and refusing to give up
examples: When she sensed a good story she was like a dog with a bone.

idioms.def: to have no chance at all
examples: He hasn't a dog's chance of passing the exam.

idioms.def: feeling very sick; vomiting a lot
used to describe a situation in which the most important aspect is being influenced and controlled by somebody/something that is not as important

idioms.idiom: (you can’t) teach an old dog new tricks
idioms.def: (you cannot) successfully make people change their ideas, methods of work, etc., when they have had them for a long time
to allow somebody to suffer or be punished in an unfair way, as if they have no value
examples: Her boss collects a big retirement cheque while she is thrown to the dogs.

idioms.idiom: why keep a dog and bark yourself?
idioms.def: if somebody can do a task for you, there is no point in doing it yourself

meanings.def: to cause you trouble for a long time
examples: be dogged by something He had been dogged by ill health all his life.
Her career was dogged by misfortune.

meanings.def: to follow somebody closely
examples: She had the impression that someone was dogging her steps.

meanings.def: to be lazy or make no effort
examples: He was criticized for dogging it after a poor performance in the game.

idioms.def: to be lazy or make no effort
examples: He was criticized for dogging it after a poor performance in the game.
